Integrated Gradients technique
The image on the left shows the original input, while the image on the right highlights the attributions for the target class.
The color intensity indicates the importance of different regions in the image for the prediction, with brighter areas having a higher impact.
In addition to Integrated Gradients, the Isee Platform offers several other explainers that can be used to understand image predictions.

'/Images/GradientInput' method is a gradient-based technique that computes attributions by taking the partial derivatives of the output with respect to the input and multiplying them with the input itself.

'/Images/SmoothGrad' explainer, which averages the gradient at several points corresponding to small perturbations around the point of interest, helping to reduce visual noise and improve explanations.
'/Images/SquareGrad' and '/Images/VarGrad' offer alternative approaches by averaging the square of the gradient and returning the variance of the gradient, respectively.
These explainers are available on the Isee Platform, and users are encouraged to try them out to gain deeper insights into their model predictions.

TF-IDF stands for Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency. It is a numerical statistic used to evaluate the importance of a word in a document relative to a collection of documents (or corpus). The TF-IDF score increases proportionally to the number of times a word appears in the document and is offset by the frequency of the word in the corpus, helping to adjust for the fact that some words appear more frequently in general.

The explanation provided uses the LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations) technique to highlight the most important words in the text that contributed to the AI system's outcome.
In this case, the AI predicted the class "HLR" with a probability of 1.00.
The highlighted words in the text, such as "notes" and "pass," indicate their significance in influencing this prediction.
LIME helps in understanding which parts of the input data are most influential in the model's decision-making process.
In the ISee Platform, we have an explainer named '/Text/LIME' that provides a similar feature influence explanation for text data.
This explainer perturbs the input data samples to train a simple model that approximates the prediction for the given instance and similar ones.
It displays a plot with the most important words for the given instance, showing both positive and negative contributions of each word to the predicted outcome.
